text:
Hello, 
We’ve been demo’ing NinjaOne. It’s patching seems solid and is improving
(automatic approvals after x days seems to be coming). 
A concern that I have with Policy structure is rigid. Machines fit into only one
Policy and the Policy includes all settings (both patching and non-patching
items). There is also no current way to dynamically assign machines to Policies
on the fly – although I think the API can help with that. 
So, if I want to blacklist a specific patch for a specific device configuration
(eg. All HP laptops), I would have to create a new Policy with all the settings
I want (patch and non-patching related), and MANUALLY apply it to the right
machines. 
To contrast, with ConnectWise Automate, I could make a new Patch Group based on
a search. The settings on the Patch Group could be set to blacklist the patch.
The Groups stack on one another (based on precedence rules), and no other
polices are effected. 
Do I recommend Automate? It’s very flexible, but it doesn’t give a great view of
how effective your patching is, and if/how out of date a machine is. I am
curious to find out which Patch Management systems do have good reporting. 
Thanks,
Shimon
